<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_dma_map:
```c
int metal_dma_map(struct metal_device *dev,
		  uint32_t dir,
		  struct metal_sg *sg_in,
		  int nents_in,
		  struct metal_sg *sg_out)
{
	int nents_out;

	if (!dev || !sg_in || !sg_out)
		return -EINVAL;
	if (!dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_map)
		return -ENODEV;

	/* memory barrier */
	if (dir == METAL_DMA_DEV_R)
		/* If it is device read, apply memory write fence. */
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_release);
	else
		/* If it is device write or r/w, apply memory r/w fence. */
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_acq_rel);
	nents_out = dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_map(dev->bus,
			dev, dir, sg_in, nents_in, sg_out);
	return nents_out;
}
```

explanation: I only flagged code fragments that declare or pass pointers that could reasonably require review for possible const-qualification. Fragments not listed were not considered suspicious for the purposes of MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 for these reasons: (1) Existing pointer declarations that are already const-qualified (for example the device name pointer) do not need investigation. (2) Non-pointer entities (integers, enums, return codes, array objects) are not relevant to this rule. (3) Calls to functions or uses of atomic operations are usages, not pointer declarations; without the callee's prototype/type information it is not possible to judge const-qualification from the call site alone. (4) Some pointers in an API are intentionally mutable because they are outputs or represent objects that are expected to be modified; such cases require semantic/contextual review (not a blanket constification) and therefore were only flagged where the declaration or parameter suggests a potential missed const qualification. Other code lines/expressions in the provided snippets do not present pointer declarations or obvious opportunities to add const and thus were not included.
